ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class taught me a ton. I had a pretty limited background, but I now feel more confident about my understanding of basics of probability and statistics.
I developed a much deeper understanding of statistical methods and better intuition in mathematical proofs.
probability theory, Lebesgue integral, hypothesis testing.
I learned the underlying theory of confidence intervals, point estimation, and hypothesis testing.
I have revised the core material in probability and statistics and I learned how to tackle harder exercises than what I was used to
Properties of estimators and statistical tests.
A strong understanding of the mathematical underpinning of probability theory and asymptotics.
Basics of measure theory, probability theory, asymptotic theory, estimation and test
I learnt a lot about basic Econometrics since this was my first graduate level course in Econometrics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Professor Andrews is a fantastic teacher. The course is very organized and the lecture notes are like a mini-bible of knowledge. It's clear he's perfected the notes and the teaching structure. Weaknesses: It's fast paced, and if you don't have a strong background you will need to work very very hard.

One TA section per week was too few. Two would have been really helpful. Also, I found the homework proofs very challenging and sometimes hard to get started. Some hints could have been really helpful to make sure I was heading in the right direction.
It could be better to spend less time on probability theory and more time on statistics.
Don Andrews and his notes were great.
The course was extremely organized.
I think the class is well designed.
The homework questions sometimes seemed to outpace the lecture material.
Strength -- well-organized class and lecture notes Weakness -- Questions of homeworks are almost the same every year

Our instructor's deeply engaging and profoundly interesting style of teaching is the biggest strength of this course. However, the assignments were sometimes too long and tough and did not add a lot of value to my learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. You probably have to take it, but it's worth it.
Clearly, it's an essential course for anyone trying to develop an economics skillset. For someone with a weak math background, a prerequisite course would be very helpful.
Yes, it lays a solid foundation.
Yes; I learned a lot; it is also mandatory for the first year PhD program.
Yes, I learned a lot.
It is the best way to gain confidence with the basis of probability and statistics at a pretty deep level.
Yes, if you have some knowledge about linear models and statistical tests but have never seen rigorous treatment of them.
Yes, this is a great course on probability and basic statistics. Professor Andrews is a great teacher.
Yes
Yes. I'm sure you can develop basic knowledge of mathematical statistics by taking this course.
Yes, I would highly recommend this course to all students in quantitative PhD programs as these concepts will be of great use in future research.
